name: l-tyrosine, n-methyl-
Reason: The structure of N-methyl-L-tyrosine consists of a benzene ring (basic unit) with additional functional groups: a hydroxyl (OH), a carboxylic acid (COOH), a methyl group on the amine (NCH3), and a side chain consisting of a CH2 connected to the amine. Starting with benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius, each functional group will affect the overall melting point of the compound. The hydroxyl group generally causes an increase in melting point due to hydrogen bonding; approximately +80 degrees Celsius for its strong hydrogen-bonding capability. The carboxylic acid group also promotes hydrogen bonding and generally adds similar or greater increases to the melting point as hydroxyl groups; another +80 degrees Celsius. The methyl group on the amine (NCH3) is not as polar and is smaller, so its contribution to the melting point will be less significant, about +10 degrees Celsius. The benzene ring will not add significantly to the melting point since it is the basic structure we are starting from. The CH2 connected to the amine is also a relatively small addition, so its effect will be minimal, roughly +5 degrees Celsius.

name: l-tyrosine, n-methyl-
Reason: N-methyl-L-tyrosine includes a phenyl ring (basic unit, benzene) which has a melting point of approximately 5.5 degrees Celsius. Starting from benzene, the influence of the hydroxyl (-OH) group, due to hydrogen bonding, can contribute significantly to an increased melting point, with an estimated increase of about +100 degrees Celsius. The carboxylic acid (COOH) group, which also forms strong hydrogen bonds, could increase the melting point further, an estimated +100 degrees Celsius. The N-methyl group (NCH3) will moderately increase melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at about +20 degrees Celsius. The additional CH2 group linked to the amine would have a nominal effect, perhaps contributing an additional +5 degrees Celsius due to increased molecular size and van der Waals interactions.

name: l-tyrosine, n-methyl-
Reason: The melting point of a compound is affected by a variety of factors including molecular weight, polarity, hydrogen bonding potential, and structural symmetry. In the case of N-methyl-L-tyrosine, the basic unit to consider is tyrosine which has a melting point of 342°C. Each functional group in the molecule will modify this value. The presence of the N-methyl group decreases the potential for hydrogen bonding compared to the primary amine in tyrosine, which generally reduces the melting point. A carboxylic acid group has the potential for strong hydrogen bonds, but since tyrosine also has this group, it would not be considered for an incremental change to the melting point in this comparison. The phenol group contributes to increased hydrogen bonding, but as it's also present in tyrosine, it doesn't lead to a change. Thus, the only significant difference between tyrosine and N-methyl-L-tyrosine for the purpose of predicting the melting point is the substitution of the N-methyl group. A diminution effect might be expected due to the interference with hydrogen bonding, which I would roughly estimate as a decrease of about 50°C compared to tyrosine.
